Equipment safety information was meticulously compiled on the ethylene oxide process.  Specifications for ethylene oxide process are collected and provided in one place for easy reference.  Details such as maximum intended inventory; safe upper and lower temperatures; safe upper and lower pressures; and codes and standards used to design, build, and operate the processes are on file at the facility.  The El Paso facility also has procedures in place that are triggered to update process safety information if there is a major change that makes existing information inaccurate.

Process Hazard Analysis 

In November 2003, a detailed process hazard analysis (PHA) was conducted for the ethylene oxide system equipment and procedures.  This PHA was further reviewed on May 26, 2005. The PHA will be updated again within a five-year period or whenever there is a major change in the process.  Based on the PHA, a list of recommended actions was developed to further improve ethylene oxide safety.  All the above recommendations have been evaluated, implemented, and documented.
Operating Procedures

The El Paso facility maintains up-to-date, accurate, written operating procedures that provide clear instructions for the ethylene oxide process.  The El Paso facility ensures effective operating practices by combining them with operating and maintenance training programs.  Standard operating procedures (SOPs) provide system descriptions, specifications, equipment inspection requirements, and operating procedures for the ethylene oxide system.  The operating procedures include connection/disconnection for ethylene oxide drums, start-up and shutdown for ethylene oxide evaporators, after-maintenance start-up for ethylene oxide evaporators, and maintenance shutdown for ethylene oxide eva

porators, ethylene oxide system emergency shutdown, start-up following an emergency shutdown, and temporary operations. Also included are the maintenance and troubleshooting procedures, including consequences of deviation and the steps to correct or avoid deviations.  The El Paso facility updates procedures whenever a change occurs that alters the steps needed to operate safely.  Operating procedures will be developed and put in place prior to any new process equipment coming on line, changes made in the handling of ethylene oxide equipment, or reconfiguration of the facilities.
Training 

El Paso facility employees presently involved in operating or maintaining the ethylene oxide process are trained in an overview of the process and detailed applicable operating and maintenance procedures.  The El Paso facility ensures that each employee newly assigned to the process is trained and tested to be competent in the operating procedures listed pertaining to their duties.  El Paso facility training program includes four elements: (1) initial training and awareness training; (2) refresher training; (3) documentation; and (4) and testing.  Each employee presently involved in operating the ethylene oxide process has been trained to receive the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out the duties and responsibilities, including ethylene oxide emergency response, as provided in the operating procedures.  

Refresher training is provided every three years or less to each employee operating the covered process to ensure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures.  In addition, the El Paso facility ensures that operators are trained in any updated or new procedures prior to startup of a process after a major change as indicated in their Management of Change and/or Pre Startup Safety Review procedures.

The ethylene oxide storage and use at the El Paso facility is subject to EPA rules, as well as the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standards.
Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
  
The El Paso facility complies with Federal Process Safety Management requirements.  The El Paso facility accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:

* Detailed management system and clear levels of responsibilities and team member roles.
* Comprehensive process safety information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors.

* Comprehensive preventive maintenance program.

* Performance of process hazard analysis of equipment and procedures with operation and maintenance staff participation and review.

* Use of state-of-the-art process and safety equipment.

* Use of accurate and effective operating procedures, written with the participation of the operators.

* High level of training of the operators and maintenance staff.

* Implementation of an incident investigation, inspection, and auditing program using qualified staff.

Chemical-specific prevention steps include availability of self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), worn by the operators during connection/disconnection of ethylene oxide supply, awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of ethylene oxide, presence of ethylene oxide detectors and alarms, flare system, two abators, and three safe cells.

The Isomedix Operations, Inc. El Paso facility uses ethylene oxide for sterilizing the health care facilities supplies (packaged products).  Ethylene oxide is highly effective in killing bacteria, insects, and fungi.  It serves as an efficient means for sterilization in systems where heat cannot be used to kill such organisms.  The use of ethylene oxide as a sterilization has been the dominant disinfection method in the United States since it was introduced, around the beginning of this century. 

As one might expect from its superior sterilization properties, ethylene oxide is a hazardous substance.  Thus, storing and handling ethylene oxide can present a risk to employees and the public without proper precautions.  The El Paso facility considers safe practices in storing and using ethylene oxide to be of primary importance and has an excellent safety record with ethylene oxide.

The El Paso facility ethylene oxide storage and usage process is subject to the Environmental Protection Agency Risk Management Program regulation.  This regulation requires submission of a Risk Management Plan (RMP).  An integral part of the RMP is a summary of policies and procedures followed to safely operate the facility, including a description of the possible consequences in case of an accident and the actions, which will be taken by the facility in an emergency.

The following information is specifically required in the RMP Executive Summary: 

* Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.
* General facility and regulated substances information.
* Summary of the accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps.
* Five-year accident history summary.
* Emergency response program summary.
* Planned changes to improve safety.

The above information for the El Paso facility ethylene oxide sterilization system is provided below.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The El Paso facility accidental release prevention

policy for ethylene oxide involves a unified approach that integrates proven technology, trains staff in operation and maintenance practices, and uses tested and proven management system practices.  All applicable procedures of the EPA Risk Management Program are adhered to, including key elements such as training, management system, and emergency response procedures. 

The El Paso facility emergency response policy involves the preparation of Emergency response Plan which is tailored to the facility and to the emergency response services available in the community, and is in compliance with the EPA Emergency Response Program requirements.  El Paso facility has prepared an Emergency Response Plan for ethylene oxide to facilitate coordination and emergency planning with offsite response officials and facilities in the event of an emergency.  The Emergency Response Plan has been coordinated with local response agencies, such as the El Paso Fire Department.  El Paso facility has an excellent record in preventing accidents from occurring.

General Facility and Regulated Substance Information

El Paso facility is located in the Vista del Sol Industrial Park, 1435 Isomedix Place El Paso, Texas.  The facility is approximately 100,000 square feet (total) with approximately 7,600 square feet utilized for storage of incoming products to be sterilized.  The facility is designed to sterilize various products using ethylene oxide.  The facility currently stores and uses ethylene oxide, a regulated toxic substance under the EPA rules in quantities less than 10, 000 lbs, but is proposing to store more than 10,000 pounds of ethylene after August 15, 2005.  Ethylene oxide is received at the El Paso facility and stored in the storage area, located east of the sterilization chambers.  The facility is equipped with an automatic fire sprinkler system, both ceiling and in rack.  The facility has four sterilizer vessels contained in the sterilizer room. The ethylene oxide supply drums ar

e bonded, grounded and chained, and only non-sparking tools are used to make drum connections.  The lines are purged with nitrogen prior to change out of drums and empty drums receive a nitrogen over-blanket in accordance with Department of Transportation requirements.  Ethylene oxide from the drums is vaporized in a steam-heated vaporizer prior to its introduction into the vessels.  The nitrogen gas is also steam heated prior to its introduction into the vessels.  The vessels are computer controlled by a programmable logic control system.  A system of passwords ensures that only authorized personnel have access to the logic control system.
    
The facility is equipped with an ethylene oxide removal and destruction system, which consists of two units: (1) the Flare System, and (2) two Donaldson Abator Units.  EtO laden air from the sterilization chambers is  delivered to the flare system after the flare undergoes a readiness testing, and air from the aeration rooms is delivered to the abator unit to combust the gas mixture and convert EtO to carbon dioxide and water. 

The EtO storage room is provided with three safe-cell systems. Each safe cell is capable of destructing 150 pounds of EtO should there be a leak. The EtO removal efficiency in the safe-cells is about 99%.  The safe-cells are activated by the EtO monitoring system (baseline monitoring system), which has an EtO sensor inside the EtO storage room.  The non-destructed EtO is exhausted through a common stack from all the three safe cells.

The facility is equipped with a 16-port continuous ethylene oxide monitor.  The results of the ethylene monitoring are continuously displayed in the Control Room.  The Alarm set point is 3 ppm ethylene oxide and an alert level is established at 0.5 ppm.  The facility is also equipped with two combustible gas sensors, located in the sterilizer room. Contractors

The El Paso facility has procedures and policies in place that ensure that contractors are properly informed of hazards, access limitations to hazardous process areas, emergency response procedures, and are prepared to safely complete the work.  The contractors are informed, prior to the initiation of the work at the site, of the applicable provisions of the emergency response plan.  The El Paso facility holds contractor safety briefings before allowing them near or in the process area, controls access to the process areas, and evaluates the contractor¿s safety performance.

Pre-Startup Safety Review and Mechanical Integrity Program

The El Paso facility ensures that a pre-startup safety review is completed for any new process covered by this regulation, or for significant modifications to an existing covered process that requires a change in the process safety information.  The El Paso facility maintains the mechanical integrity of process equipment to help prevent equipment failures that could endanger workers, the public, or the environment.  The El Paso facility mechanical integrity program includes the following:

* Written procedures for maintaining mechanical integrity through inspection and testing of process equipment, based on instructions of equipment vendors, industry codes and practice, and prior operating experience.
* Implementation of the written procedures by performing inspections and tests on process equipment at specified intervals.

* Training of maintenance personnel in preventive maintenance program procedures: safe work practices such as lockout/tagout, line or equipment opening, and avoidance and correction of unsafe conditions; and safe use and application of special equipment and/or unique tools.

Hot Work Permits and Management of Change 

The El Paso facility requires employees and contractors to employ safe work practices when performing

Hot Work in, on, or around the covered process.  The El Paso facility uses a permitting and training program to ensure that hot work is monitored and conducted safely on or near a process involving ethylene oxide.

The El Paso facility provides a system and approach to maintain and implement any management of change or modifications to equipment, procedures, chemicals, and processing conditions.  This system allows El Paso facility staff to identify and review safety hazards or provide additional safety, process, or chemical information to existing data before the proposed change would either compromise system safety or require training to be completed.

Internal Compliance Audits

Internal compliance audits will be conducted every three years to verify compliance with the programs and procedures contained in the RMP.  The El Paso facility will assemble an audit team that will include personnel knowledgeable in the Risk Management Program rule and in the process.  This team will evaluate whether the prevention program satisfies the requirements of the Risk Management Program rule and whether the prevention program is sufficient to help ensure safe operation of the process.  The results of the audit will be documented, recommendations resolved, and appropriate enhancements to the prevention program will be implemented.

Incident Investigation

The El Paso facility investigates all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release (serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment) so that similar accidents can be prevented.  An investigation team is assembled and the investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident.  The results of the investigation are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate process enhancements are implemented.  Information found during the investigation is reviewed by affected staff and added or used to revise operating and maintenance procedures.  There have been no such incidents invol

ving the El Paso facility ethylene oxide system.

Five-Year Accident History Summary

No ethylene oxide releases that could have caused safety or health hazard (deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place) occurred at the El Paso facility during the last five years.

Emergency Response Program Summary

The El Paso facility is a non-responding facility, which means that the facility employees will not respond to ethylene oxide accidental relaese.  Instead the facility has coordinated with the local response agency to respond to any ethylene oxide release that may occur at the facility.

The main elements of the emergency response plan are: (1) initial discovery equipment and procedure, (2) response to an emergency, including procedures for immediate action and internal notifications, and (3) procedures for external notifications, including coordination with local agencies. 

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Numerous changes to improve safety (recommended actions) were identified for the ethylene oxide system equipment and procedures in November 2003, when a process hazard analysis was performed.  This PHA was again reviewed on May 26, 2005.  All the recommendations have been evaluated and documented.
